item.description:
With more than half a decade having now passed since the release of Dynasty Warriors 9 , to say that franchise fans are pretty excited about Dynasty Warriors: Origins would perhaps be a bit of an understatement. It's by far the best-looking Dynasty Warriors game to date, and, if the game's recently released demo is anything to go by, it looks set to be the series' most exciting installment as well.

Given all of the anticipation and excitement, it should come as no surprise to learn that there are a ton of people trying to find out the release time for Dynasty Warriors: Origins . Thankfully, by looking at some of the digital storefronts through which the game can be purchased, it's pretty easy to find accurate release times, as well as information about how to play Dynasty Warriors: Origins early.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins Release Times

Like a lot of other video games released these days, Dynasty Warriors: Origins will be released at midnight, local time , with local time being determined by the region of the player's digital storefront account. It's worth noting that the US PlayStation Store operates on EST, meaning those living in other North American timezones will get to start playing the game a little earlier. As for the release date, players with early access will be able to start playing Dynasty Warriors: Origins on January 14, while those with the standard edition of the game will gain access on January 17.

item.title: Monopoly GO: How to Get Caboose Token
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How To Get Caboose Token in Monopoly GO
  • How To Reach The Bank of Monopoly in Monopoly GO

While Monopoly GO follows the same rules as the classic board game, it introduces some exciting new features, like the ability to customize board tokens, shields, and even emojis. Every new season, there are a bunch of fun collectibles for players to win that can be used to personalize your boards even further.

In addition to Mr. Lucky Dice and Tycoon Trust tokens, the Bank of Monopoly also offers the Caboose token as a collectible for players, a nod to the classic railroad theme that has been a part of Monopoly for generations. If you want to add this token to your Monopoly GO shelves, read on.

How To Get Caboose Token in Monopoly GO

The Caboose token looks exactly like a caboose, which is a small car at the very end of a freight train. Having the Caboose token would be cool, especially when you land on the Railroad tiles on the Monopoly GO board. This makes it a highly-sought after item for those who want to stand out from the crowd.

Similar to Mr. Lucky Dice and Tycoon Trust tokens, you can get the rare Caboose token by opening treasure chests in the Bank of Monopoly Board in Monopoly GO . At the time of writing, it’s exclusive to the Bank of Monopoly and cannot be found elsewhere.

While some players may be lucky enough to win it on their first visit to the Bank of Monopoly, others may need to try a few more times. Keep visiting the Bank of Monopoly and opening treasure chests, and you'll eventually unlock this special reward.

How To Reach The Bank of Monopoly in Monopoly GO

You can reach the Bank of Monopoly every ten boards you complete in Monopoly GO . As you play and build landmarks on different boards, you're steadily moving towards the next Bank of Monopoly level. After completing ten boards, the Bank of Monopoly level will become available.

You can win nine different rewards in the Bank of Monopoly, depending on where you land. To get your hands on exclusive board tokens like the Caboose Token, you need to land on the treasure vault tiles, which may take a few attempts. Keep building and visiting the Bank of Monopoly, and you’ll eventually add this token to your collection.

If you want to know how close you are to the next Bank of Monopoly, you can check the Map from the in-game menu.

item.title: 8 Best RPGs For Story-Driven Gameplay With Minimal Combat
item.description:
Summary

  • cRPGs evolved from combat-focused games to storytelling, offering players the choice to avoid violent encounters.
  • Torment: Tides of Numenera and Age of Decadence prioritize diplomacy over combat, rewarding players with a rich narrative experience.
  • Games like The Council, Outer Worlds, and Fallout: New Vegas emphasize player freedom, offering engaging stories with dialogue-based gameplay.

Computer-driven roleplaying games originated from pen-and-paper roleplaying games, which themselves were an offshoot of tactical war games played with dice, models, and a battle board. It's no surprise that most cRPGs carry this element of combat in their DNA.

That being said, just as tabletop games like Dungeons & Dragons gradually drifted away from a pure-combat experience, so too have games played with a keyboard and mouse gone from hack-and-slash to story-oriented, with some games, in particular, putting a special emphasis on making story beats, dialogue, and plot twists the main game loop.

Torment: Tides of Numenera

Using Diplomacy And Tact To Win The Day

There are many fights in Torment: Tides of Numenea , but the game is designed in such a way that most combat encounters can be avoided for those with a silver tongue. As experience points are handed out for the completion of quests, players who wish to play the game for the story rather than to test their tactical finesse will not find themselves falling behind.

The efficiency with which fights can be avoided or resolved through wordplay rather than swordplay depends on the player's build. Taking the "nano" class has its advantages in this area, but the best way to go for those looking to enjoy a good story is the "jack" with the "charming" descriptor and focus on the "persuasion" and "perception" skills.

Age of Decadence

Buying Bypasses With Lies And Wealth

Although Age of Decadence takes place in a fictional setting, there is a large emphasis on realism. Players explore a Romanesque empire filled with danger and mistrust, where a fight against multiple opponents, unlike other cRPGs, can quickly mean "game over."

However, it is entirely possible to traverse the challenges of Age of Decadence by taking a diplomatic approach, namely by taking the silver-tongued "grifter" or trade-savvy "merchant' backgrounds, focusing on the "charisma" stat, and focusing heavily on the "disguise," "etiquette," "persuasion," "streetwise," and "trading" civil skills.

The Council

Solving Problems With Skills Of A More Enlightened Age

Not all dangerous situations involve weapons, and not all monsters come with glowing red eyes or savage claws. The Council puts players behind the eyes of Louis de Richet, a member of a secret order who must investigate the disappearance of his mother on a private island filled with powerful historical figures.

While the threat of violence looms over the story in The Council right from the get-go, there is no way to fight the monsters staying on the island (even if they deserve it) as player creation involves making Louis a detective, diplomat, or occultist, each bringing their own advantages and disadvantages to the investigation.

The Outer Worlds

Worlds Of Possibility

Upon its release, some critics gave the Outer Worlds lower marks for its length. However, what it lacked in longevity it more than makes up for in player freedom. There is plenty of violence to be had in the colonies for those looking for it (there is even an ending predicated on the player killing every single NPC in the game).

Conversely, if players are interested in an experience driven by dialogue and a well-written story, they need only invest points in speech skills and sneaking. Doing so will lead to the player finding more interpersonal tidbits about NPCs and companions and experiencing the worlds without bashing skulls in or melting too many life forms down to a red, ashy goo.

Planescape: Torment

Considered One Of The Early Great Storytelling Achievements In cRPGs

In any discussion about good storytelling in video games, it is likely that Planescape: Torment will come up. Although enemies such as guards and bandits are still prevalent across the map, it is possible to de-escalate tensions with high charisma, intelligence, and wisdom stats.

Failing that, sneaking or running away is often a viable play. That being said, Planescape is still a product of its time, and there will come moments when fighting is the only option. That being said, much of the time when combat is mandatory stems from optional areas and quests.

Gamedec

Solving Virtual Crimes Rather Than Causing Them

Set in a world dominated by virtual worlds, the player fills the shoes of a "gamedec," a cross between a detective and a troubleshooting software engineer. The virtual world has become as unsafe as the real one, and so getting to the bottom of a case means the difference between fun and fatality for its inhabitants.

Although the are no enemy encounters in Gamedec, the story likes to go down deep, dark places. Depending on the player's deduction skills (or lack thereof), characters in Gamedec can experience a fate worse than a violent death.

Fallout: New Vegas

A Silver Tongue, A Gold Rush, And A Platinum Chip

Obsidian is known for leaning on their writing chops in their games, and unlike Bethesda's vision for the Fallout series, Fallout: New Vegas offers players a way to be the most violent Road Warrior -wannabe in the post-apocalyptic Mojave Desert, or the most peace-loving, depending on their ability to stay out of sight or charm the pants off of greasy grifters, anachronistic gangsters, psychopathic slavers, and other trappings of dark Americana.

New Vegas famously allows players to complete the game without putting a single body in the ground, including the final boss (if they played their cards right and lined up the right skills before the encounter). Not only that, but the expertly assembled story is one of the finest in RPG history, meaning slippery pacifist types will have a lot to chew on for eschewing the world of over-the-top violence.

Disco Elysium

The Cop That Asks Questions First, Then Shoots Into An Existential Crisis Later

With a literal series of novels as a background for the world (although only one novel, The Sacred and Terrible Air , was ever written), Disco Elysium wants nothing more than to breathe the fumes of a new world onto its players, and it does so by shunning regular combat encounters for long, beautifully intricate dialogue trees with over a million words in the script and a reactive world.

With over a million lines of dialogue, there was hardly room for a combat system, but besides the ever-present economic violence put upon by the owners of capital against the workers of Elysium, there are (at least two) moments of violence that might be considered "final test" style boss battles, although they are handled somewhat differently than they would be in a game with a combat system.

item.title: 7 Best Open-World Games With Stories Told Through Exploration
item.description:
Summary

  • Environmental storytelling in open-world games enriches the players' experience by weaving hidden narratives into diverse locations.
  • Titles like Red Dead Redemption 2 , Skyrim , and Elden Ring excel at creating immersive stories embedded within their worlds.
  • STALKER 2 , Fallout 4 , and The Division feature richly detailed environments that reveal captivating tales of past events through exploration.

In the open-world genre, environmental storytelling can significantly enhance the players' experience, making exploration and the world itself far more engaging. Uncovering hidden narratives within various locations – stories that only reveal themselves to players who closely observe their surroundings – adds depth to exploration and looting. Even small, seemingly insignificant areas can hold clues about what transpired there, keeping players invested in uncovering these details. This approach is especially crucial for games with a heavy emphasis on free-roaming, where completing the journey can take over 100 hours.

The effectiveness of environmental storytelling often depends on the game's setting. Urban or post-apocalyptic worlds tend to lend themselves to dense, diverse narratives, allowing players to piece together the mysteries of those who once lived there. However, even traditional fantasy games with rich lore can offer surprisingly engaging hidden stories, rewarding players who delve deep into their environments. Below, let's explore some standout open-world games that excel at delivering exceptional environmental storytelling, setting them apart within the genre.

1 Red Dead Redemption 2

Wild West Setting With Some Of The Most Believable NPCs

Red Dead Redemption 2 focuses more on forging your own path through the wilderness, with environmental storytelling emerging less frequently than in some other open-world games below. However, when players stumble upon an abandoned ranch, camp, shack, or cave that once housed someone, they're often left with intriguing fragments of a story – provoking thought but offering few clear answers. Rockstar's reputation for crafting intricate mysteries that players continue to analyze for years is on full display in RDR2 , making each discovery feel meaningful.

What sets Red Dead Redemption 2 apart isn't just its detailed locations ripe for exploration, but also the smaller, optional stories woven into towns and cities. These moments, often involving NPCs, aren't marked as side quests but reward careful players with hidden opportunities. Whether helping or robbing people or piecing together subtle environmental clues to turn a profit as an outlaw, RDR2 offers a wealth of immersive experiences that make its world feel alive and unpredictable.

2 Skyrim

Timeless Destination That Every Fantasy Lover Must Visit

Like many Bethesda titles, The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim has stood as a benchmark for environmental storytelling for well over a decade, offering a vast world brimming with adventures and tales at every turn. From the very beginning, players are free to choose their own path – whether delving into deep caves filled with treasures, exploring ancient ruins shrouded in mystery, or wandering through bustling cities alive with NPCs and small errands.

Among fantasy open-world games, few can rival Skyrim 's unparalleled sense of freedom paired with its rich environmental storytelling – a key factor behind its enduring popularity in both the RPG and open-world genres. Each new location feels fresh and exciting, even after dozens or even hundreds of hours, thanks to the game's masterful balance between subtle lore-driven narratives and engaging, direct storylines.

3 Elden Ring

Layered Lore Offering Endless Discoveries Across Each Region

In many ways, Elden Ring presents a post-apocalyptic world where cataclysmic events have already unfolded. The Elden Ring itself has been shattered, and many of the once-mighty Demigods have fallen far from their prime. As Tarnished, players traverse countless war-torn fortresses and castles, alongside desolate or corrupted settlements, villages, and entire cities. Only the most observant players can piece together the history of these intricate locations, uncovering subtle narratives through environmental details and items placed with deliberate intent. The Lands Between feels alive in its decay, rewarding those who seek to unravel its mysteries.

FromSoftware, masters of environmental storytelling, play to their strengths in Elden Ring . The game's lore is incredibly deep and layered, with fans still uncovering connections between seemingly unrelated characters, events, and locations. This intricate design ensures that the world of Elden Ring continues to captivate players long after they've left its hauntingly beautiful landscapes and overcome all of its challenges.

4 Cyberpunk 2077

Futuristic, Immersive City Unlike Any Other

Cyberpunk 2077 marks a significant evolution in environmental storytelling for CD Projekt Red, building on the foundation laid by The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt . The game leverages its futuristic setting – a sprawling, dark megacity where cultures, influences, and human values collide in a truly unique blend. Night City is one of the most ambitious and expansive urban environments ever created in a video game, with the studio's meticulous, hand-crafted approach evident in every detail.

From dozens of explorable buildings with richly detailed interiors to apartments that capture the essence of their owners at a glance, the world brims with personality. Gritty slums, secret warehouses, and the expansive wastelands surrounding the city further add to its depth. Night City itself feels like the game's central character, telling countless stories beyond the main narrative, side quests, and jobs, all through its vibrant and immersive environmental design.

5 STALKER 2: Heart of Chornobyl

Almost Every Location Tells A Story With Admirable Attention To Detail

STALKER 2: Heart of Chornobyl is a true haven for explorers, with the Zone brought to life in stunning detail. Equal parts dangerous and beautiful, the Zone is packed with mysteries and rewards for observant stalkers who take the time to learn its rules. Beyond the main and side quests – or even the thrill of artifact hunting – STALKER 2 is brimming with small stories, random encounters, and, most notably, well-hidden stashes. Claiming every stash is no easy task, but players are often rewarded not only with valuable items but also with a glimpse into the tale of its previous owner or the unfortunate events that led to its abandonment.

One of the greatest strengths of STALKER 2 is the layered complexity of its world and narrative. The game masterfully blends the real-life story and consequences of the Chornobyl disaster with fictionalized elements, creating exclusion zones inspired by real-world locations while adding imaginative twists of its own. This approach results in an immersive, realistic world that appeals to both newcomers and series veterans, with countless nods to the earlier games for long-time fans to uncover.

6 The Division

Detailed Streets And Abandoned Buildings Perfectly Capture Collapsed Cities

Tom Clancy's The Division was eerily prescient, depicting the devastating collapse of major U.S. cities due to a deadly virus – a scenario that feels even more unsettling in the post-Covid real-world pandemic. Combining the haunting allure of post-apocalyptic environments with a uniquely atmospheric Christmas setting, The Division stands out as one of Ubisoft's finest examples of environmental storytelling and one of the most immersive in the open-world genre.

Even today, the game impresses with meticulously detailed streets, littered with remnants of chaos, and its abandoned apartments that tell countless tragic stories of survivors struggling to endure. The Division doesn't rely on elaborate cutscenes to convey its dark, chilling narratives – it places them directly in front of the players, woven seamlessly into its world.

While The Division 2 carries on this legacy with its own strong environmental storytelling, the sunlit streets of Washington, D.C. lack the same distinct charm as snow-covered, holiday-tinged New York. That said, which setting resonates more ultimately comes down to personal preference.

7 Fallout 4

Every Corner Of This Vast Wasteland Holds Secrets Waiting To Be Discovered

Surpassing Skyrim was no small feat, yet Bethesda managed to do so brilliantly in the realm of environmental storytelling with Fallout 4 . The previous entry, Fallout 3 , had already set a high bar, showcasing the franchise's unique ability to weave subtle and nuanced stories through exploration alone. However, Fallout 4 elevated this aspect with a much larger and denser wasteland, packed with countless hidden locations and multi-story buildings, each room offering intriguing discoveries or small, thought-provoking scenarios for players to unravel.

Every step through the Commonwealth – the city of Boston and its surrounding Massachusetts region – is filled with new revelations. From tragic or darkly amusing tales of ill-fated settlers and vault dwellers to snapshots of everyday life and struggles in a post-apocalyptic world, the game offers endless moments of discovery. While there's some repetitiveness in its quest structure, particularly with settlement-related tasks, exploration remains engaging for hundreds of hours. Players are rewarded not just with valuables or crafting materials, but with something far more meaningful – stories and personal moments that breathe life into the wasteland.

item.title: Hearts Of Iron 4: Best Combat Widths
item.description:
Summary

  • Combat Width 21 offers flexible options for incursions, balancing defense, and offense in most terrains.
  • Combat Width 13 is suited for smaller unit counts, performing well in defensive lines in certain terrains.
  • Combat Width 19 can reinforce defenses effectively, ideal for split attacks to support the defensive line.

With Hearts of Iron 4 considered one of the most comprehensive grand strategy games set in World War 2, fans of wargames may appreciate the level of depth the game offers, especially from the perspective of wartime production and overall warfare. After players research improvements and other advancements for their ground troops, they can engage in intense land battles against enemy forces - with much of their units' strength reliant on Combat Width .

Combat Width in the game is defined as the overall concentration of a faction's ground forces. Terrain determines the base width and flanking width available to players, with elements such as flanking, naval attacks, and paradrops adding to a side's Combat Width before engagements begin. Considering how Combat Width is determined by its encompassing battalions, fans may wonder just how much is "enough" when trying to engage enemies as practically as possible. With the game offering different engagement setups, just which Combat Widths are the most practical in the game?

Updated on January 12, 2025, by Rhenn Taguiam: With Hearts of Iron 4 about to release its Graveyard of Empires Country Pack sometime this Q1 2025, fans of the franchise will now be able to help Afghanistan, India, Iran, and Iraq become superpowers who refuse to bow down to existing empires at the time. However, while the nations will receive respective upgrades and new additions to their National Focii, fans need to make sure they can maximize these countries’ offerings - especially in combat. Thankfully, understanding the right Combat Widths to use in fights can help any nation stand a chance in intense wars - especially when Hearts of Iron 4 emphasizes logistics just as much as combat power. Among must-try Combat Widths include one decent for general flexibility, two defensive Widths for players to try, and one for specialized terrain.

While not necessarily providing the same flexibility as other higher-ranking Combat Widths, players who want a sizable unit for most terrain will appreciate something along the lines of a Combat Width 21 9/1 set up as a flexible enough arrangement for both defense and offense.

Due to geography, Combat Width 21 seems to be effective in Europe, especially when working in tandem with Combat Width 27 and Combat Width 42.
